page.title: 01Stiffkey & Cockthorpe
page.content: Stiffkey river crossed by A149 North Norfolk coast road; estuary has gradually silted up. {Stiffkey village}now inland, sheltered by tree-bearing mounds of terminal moraine deposited in ice age. Name may derive from 'the Stowes', hillock to south of Parish thought to be site of ancient 'moot' or, possibly, from 'sticks' (perhaps once 'stughs' hence 'staves' / 'stages') stuck in ground to build up marshland + 'quay'. Famous for cockles known as{'Stewkey {Blues'}but cockling no longer major industry. {Cockthorpe hamlet}overlooking valley may be site of ancient hill-top settlement above flood level. Despite change both villages retain much old character, unique beauty and independence.
